node.text:
In 1878 artist #JulesTavernier painted "Dance in a Subterranean Roundhouse at Clear Lake, California," depicting a ceremonial dance of the #ElemPomo known as mfom Xe, or “people dance,” in an underground roundhouse, Xe-xwan, at Clear Lake, California.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
While Tavernier’s painting celebrates the rich vitality of Elem Pomo culture, it also exposes the threat posed by settlers who were then operating a toxic mercury mine on the community’s ancestral homelands.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
In this film, Elem Pomo cultural leader and regalia maker Robert Geary; Dry Creek Pomo scholar Sherrie Smith-Ferri, PhD; and Eastern Pomo artist and curator Meyo Marrufo share the importance of the landscape and natural materials in Pomo basketry and explore the environmental and cultural impact of mining and land loss, as well as the continuum of Pomo ceremony at the site.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
See this painting alongside more than 50 works in "Jules Tavernier and the Elem Pomo," opening Monday, August 16.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Learn more at the link in bio.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
#TavernierElemPomo⁣⁣⁣
@metamericanwing

node.title: Jules Tavernier and the Elem Pomo

node.text:
Gardeners, take note! 🌱 Go behind the scenes at the @metcloisters with Assistant Horticulturist Yvette Weaver as she takes us from greenhouse to garden. ⁣
⁣
The Met Cloisters is open! Tap the link in bio to learn more about this serene medieval museum in upper Manhattan—and to plan your next excursion.

node.title: How To Propagate the Martock Fava Bean

node.text:
A true weekend anthem. 💤 ⁣
⁣
Born July 31, 1897, Ignacio Fleta was one of the most important Spanish classical guitar builders of the 20th century. ⁣
⁣
This guitar in The Met collection, built by Fleta in 1953, is played here by Swedish musician Mattias Schulstad (@mattiasguitar).⁣
⁣
Did You Know: The term "Spanish guitar" has been used differently across time and cultures. Today it's often used interchangeably with the "classical guitar" and is certainly not limited to instruments made in Spain (though Ignacio Fleta was indeed from Spain).⁣
⁣
Learn more at the link in bio.⁣
⁣
🎶 "Come, Heavy Sleep (Molto Tranquillo)" from Nocturnal After John Dowland, op.70 by Benjamin Britten (1913–1976) ⁣
⁣🎸 Ignacio Fleta (Spanish, 1897–1977). Guitar, 1953. Spruce, rosewood. #MetMusic

node.text:
⁣ ⁣⁣
⁣
"To Evan –⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
We emerge from isolation into a world both familiar⁣⁣⁣
And alien.⁣⁣⁣
We work tirelessly to keep the demons at bay,⁣⁣⁣
But still the damage is done.⁣⁣⁣
The smoke from the west reaches the east, and makes the south more violent ⁣⁣⁣
The north less predictable.⁣⁣⁣
One way out of this reality –⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Stay grounded⁣⁣⁣
Be attentive⁣⁣⁣
Connect⁣⁣⁣
And BREATHE"⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
—Matthew Evan Taylor (@matthewevantaylor⁣⁣⁣)⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
During a time plagued by isolation, how can musicians compose collaboratively when separated by vast distances? ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Tune in each month for #PostcardsToTheMet—a #MetLiveArts project from composer and solo saxophonist Matthew Evan Taylor's, in collaboration with Metropolis Ensemble and RAJAS. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
This month's episode features musician Evan Runyon on double bass.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Watch the full series on our IGTV channel for a glimpse into Taylor's creative process as he exchanges concepts with musicians across the globe for his piece "Life Returns," which will be presented at The Met in spring 2022.⁣⁣⁣⁣ Tap the link in bio for more.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
@metroensemble⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
@junipercreativellc⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
@rajna_music

node.title: Matthew Evan Taylor: Postcards to The Met—Postcard 5

node.text:
📸 The New Woman of the 1920s was a powerful expression of modernity—a global phenomenon that embodied an ideal of female empowerment based on real women making revolutionary changes in life and art. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Opening this Friday, July 2, "The New Woman Behind the Camera" explores the work of the diverse "new" women across the globe who embraced photography as a mode of professional and artistic expression from the 1920s through the 1950s, when women stood at the forefront of experimentation with the camera. ⁣⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣
Tap the link in bio to learn more—and tune in on July 8 (7 pm ET) for a virtual, curator-led tour through the exhibition. #NewWomanPhotographers ⁣@metphotographs
⁣
🎥 Video produced by The National Gallery of Art, Washington. @ngadc

node.title: The New Woman Behind the Camera

node.text:
⁣”To Rajna —⁣⁣
⁣
Unless we listen to our hearts,⁣⁣
Time will pass imperceptibly.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Once we listen to our hearts⁣⁣
We vocalize the future we wish to see.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
The challenge—to make our marks within the time we have."⁣⁣
⁣⁣
In this month’s installment of #PostcardsToTheMet, hear the music of Rajna Swaminathan, acclaimed mrudangam musician.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
How can musicians compose collaboratively from across the globe? Tune in each month to this #MetLiveArts project from composer and solo saxophonist Matthew Evan Taylor, in collaboration with Metropolis Ensemble and RAJAS, for a glimpse into Taylor's creative process to exchange musical concepts globally for his piece "Life Returns," which will be presented at The Met in spring 2022.⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Watch the full series on our IGTV channel, and tap the link in bio for more.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
@matthewevantaylor⁣⁣⁣
@metroensemble⁣⁣⁣
@junipercreativellc⁣⁣⁣
@rajna_music

node.title: Matthew Evan Taylor: Postcards to The Met—Postcard 4⁣⁣

node.text:
Further proof that New York City is very much alive.

Juxtaposing cellular activity shown under a microscope with footage of New York City, filmmaker Hilary Harris envisions the 1975 metropolis as a complex living organism. 

Explore more #FromTheVaults at the link in bio.

node.text:
Transport yourself to sunnier days and enjoy a meditative tour of The Met’s 2021 Roof Garden Commission by Alex Da Corte—featuring the beloved Sesame Street character Big Bird—and sweeping views of New York City from the #CantorRoof.

Check out all #VirtualMuseumMile programs, videos, and activities at the link in bio. #MMF2021

node.title: Silent Gallery Tour—Alex Da Corte, "As Long as the Sun Lasts"

node.text:
Ever wondered what it's like to wear a suit of armor? What about dancing in it? ⁣
⁣
Join #MetKids Karlissah, 9, and Naomi, 11, as they break it down with dancers from the street dance company @itsshowtimenyc in this flashback that takes us inside our @metarmsandarmor galleries in honor of today's Virtual Museum Mile Festival. ⁣
⁣
📲 Check out more videos and activities at the link in bio. ⁣
⁣
#VirtualMuseumMile ⁣
#MMF2021⁣

node.text:
Hey #VirtualMuseumMile go-ers! Join us on a trip through the Temple of Dendur—a beloved gift from the Egyptian government to the U.S.

Built by Ceasar Augustus in 10 B.C., this monument is dedicated not only to the goddess Isis and other Egyptian deities, but also to several Indigenous Nubian gods and two local saints.

Keep an eye out for the Sphinx of Hatshepsut and other ancient Egyptian sculptures that surround the temple in Gallery 131.

node.title: Silent Gallery Tour—The Temple of Dendur

node.accessibility_caption: A light-skinned man stands in front of “The Unicorn in Captivity,” a medieval tapestry on view at The Met Cloisters. Their shirt is off and their back is turned to the camera revealing a tattoo across their back that is nearly identical to the center scene of the tapestries, showing a white unicorn, a surrounding fence, and lush foliage.

node.text:
The perfect tattoo doesn’t exi—⁣ 🤭🥺😍
⁣⁣⁣
Absolutely in awe of this forever tribute to “The Unicorn in Captivity” at the @metcloisters—one of seven in the Unicorn Tapestries series from the late Middle Ages. #MetTwinning has officially reached new heights. 🦄✨ ⁣
⁣
Thank you so much to tattoo artist Esther Garcia (@butterstinker) and client @izziecontagious for sharing your talents and phenomenal images!

node.accessibility_caption: A light-skinned man stands in front of “The Unicorn in Captivity,” a medieval tapestry on view at The Met Cloisters. Their shirt is off and their back is turned to the camera revealing a tattoo across their back that is nearly identical to the center scene of the tapestries, showing a white unicorn, a surrounding fence, and lush foliage.
A close-up of the tattoo, revealing its immense details including the fruit on the tree behind the unicorn, flowers throughout, and a small bit of blood on the chained up unicorn.
An even closer view of the tattooed unicorn, showing its mane, horn, goatee, and chained neck.

A colorful scene featuring two Japanese women with long black hair and bright kimonos engaged in a variety of activities within a palace. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣

node.text:
A stroke of brilliance—literally ✨⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It's #WorldCalligraphyDay! So here's a fun fact: These works are from the oldest dated and complete example of "The Tale of Genji"—the monumental classic of Japanese literature. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Ryūjo (Tatsujo) completed this in 1594. A close look at the calligraphy (→ swipe!) reveals she was a talented, high-ranking woman intimately familiar  with chirashi-gaki, or "scattered writing"—a specialty of women calligraphers in which columns of script are playfully rearranged to create a dynamic visual effect.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
These works come from a larger series of five 16th-century handscrolls that retell all 54 chapters of the 11th-century tale authored by the court lady Murasaki Shikibu.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Explore the full handscroll at the link in bio, or see it up close in "Japan: A History of Style" beginning August 28.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
🎨 Ryūjo (Tatsujo) (Japanese, active late 16th century). The Tale of Genji (Scroll 2, sections 20-16), 1594. #ArtsOfJapan⁣⁣

A fair-skinned, blond woman—identified as the actress Angela Kinney—wears a black face mask, a floral top, jeans, and red converse shoes, while standing next to the Sphinx of Hatshepsut in The Met's Ancient Egyptian Galleries. node.text:
We didn't *account* for such a *purrfect* visitor near the Temple of *Dunder* heh heh...⁣
⁣
Okay enough awful (awf-ice?) puns—guess who stopped by for our latest #MetCameo! ⁣
⁣
@AngelaKinsey and her family spent some time with the sphinx of Hatshepsut, a reminder of an earlier time in her life:⁣⁣

"When I was 21, I lived in New York City in an apartment by the Lincoln Tunnel. My bedroom would turn yellow, red, and green with the traffic light. I didn't have a view of anything except for that intersection and another brick building. So I would go to The Met every chance I got to escape and daydream. 

I fell in love with the Egyptian Wing and spent hours walking around. Every piece has an amazing story. This summer I was able to take my children to The Met, and I couldn't wait for them to see the Egyptian artifacts. 

How awesome is this sphinx of the pharaoh Hatshepsut?! She is said to have reigned for 21 years! When people think of pharaohs, they usually think of men, but women held the position, too.

I was so glad I got to show her and the rest of the Egyptian Wing to my children! We can't wait to go back!"
⁣⁣
🎨 Sphinx of Hatshepsut. New Kingdom, Dynasty 18, ca. 1479–1458 B.C. Joint reign of Hatshepsut and Thutmose III.  On view in Gallery 131.

node.accessibility_caption: A fair-skinned, blond woman—identified as the actress Angela Kinney—wears a black face mask, a floral top, jeans, and red converse shoes, while standing next to the Sphinx of Hatshepsut in The Met's Ancient Egyptian Galleries. The sphinx sculpture is carved out of a speckled stone and is placed atop a black pedestal.

A similar photo but in this image, she has her hands extended, mirroring the paws of the sphinx next to her. The sphinx sculpture is carved out of a speckled stone and is placed atop a black pedestal.

node.text:
In 1878 artist #JulesTavernier painted "Dance in a Subterranean Roundhouse at Clear Lake, California," depicting a ceremonial dance of the #ElemPomo known as mfom Xe, or “people dance,” in an underground roundhouse, Xe-xwan, at Clear Lake, California.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
While Tavernier’s painting celebrates the rich vitality of Elem Pomo culture, it also exposes the threat posed by settlers who were then operating a toxic mercury mine on the community’s ancestral homelands.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
In this film, Elem Pomo cultural leader and regalia maker Robert Geary; Dry Creek Pomo scholar Sherrie Smith-Ferri, PhD; and Eastern Pomo artist and curator Meyo Marrufo share the importance of the landscape and natural materials in Pomo basketry and explore the environmental and cultural impact of mining and land loss, as well as the continuum of Pomo ceremony at the site.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
See this painting alongside more than 50 works in "Jules Tavernier and the Elem Pomo," opening Monday, August 16.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Learn more at the link in bio.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
#TavernierElemPomo⁣⁣⁣
@metamericanwing

node.text:
Is this the real-life inspiration for...Boss Baby?? ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Of course not. That'd be crazy, this baby is from the 16th century. But he may as well be. Meet Garzia, the ninth child of Cosimo and Eleonora di' Medici. ⁣
⁣
Painted by Bronzino in the 1550s, this portrait of the toddler is rife with powerful symbols.⁣ The orange blossom in his left hand signals innocence and purity. 🌼 ⁣
⁣
And take a peek at the chain he's holding—it has a ring with a horn-shaped, dark material set in gold mounts for teething and a pendant crystal to protect against witches.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Meet more members of the Medici family at the link in bio—and visit "The Medici: Portraits & Politics, 1512–1570" through October 11. #MetMedici⁣⁣
⁣⁣
🎨  Bronzino (Agnolo di Cosimo di Mariano) (Italian, 1503–1572). Garzia de' Medici, ca. 1550. @museoprado, Madrid (P000005). On view in Gallery 999.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
[Image description: An oil painting of a fair-skinned blond toddler identified as Garzia de' Medici posing against a deep blue background. The toddler is dressed in an intricate red and gold ensemble with a pearl and gold lace collar. The chain he holds in one hand has a ring with a horn-shaped, dark material set in gold mounts—probably a piece of horn, bone, or antler—and a pendant crystal. In his other hand, he grasps a white orange blossom.]

New Yorkers! Looking for a creative outlet for your artsy #MetKids? 🎨⁣
⁣
Every Thursday this August, join us outside the Museum! Stop by to pick up a free art kit for children ages 3–11 and join us to get creative out on The Met Plaza.⁣
⁣
Tap the link in bio to learn more. ⁣
⁣
📸: Filip Wolak

The two children are sitting on the steps photographed from above. The young boy is looking down, immersed in coloring and art-making. The little girl, also busy art-making, looks up at the camera and flashes a wide smile.

node.text:
Is it a sculpture or a book! Let’s say both, shall we? The ideal object of affection for art- and book-lovers alike on #NationalBookLoversDay.⁣
⁣
Lauren Clay’s phenomenal work “Subtle Body” is what’s known as a tunnel book—as the pages expand, viewers are drawn deeper and deeper into the vivid and colorful landscape. 📚🌀 ⁣
⁣
Book-lovers! Head over to @metlibrary and @costumeinstitutelibrary for more literary works of art.

node.accessibility_caption: A blue cloisonné double vase with red, orange, blue, white, and gold  details. Between the two cases is a large gold phoenix standing on top of a bird and bear.

node.text:
To the #Olympics2021 champions and heroes all over the world—we salute you. 🥇 🥈 🥉 Congrats! 
⁣
Featuring a phoenix on one side and a dragon on the other, this ornate cloisonné vessel sits on a yingxiong bei, or hero's cup, referring to the bird (ying) and the bear (xiong) upon which it stands.⁣
⁣
Chinese objects like this—with two narrow vertical compartments connected by a carving of a mythical bird—have often been referred to as "champion vases" in Western scholarship (perhaps a loose translation of hero's cup). ⁣⁣

See it on view now in "Masters and Masterpieces: Chinese Art from the Florence and Herbert Irving Collection." 
⁣⁣
🎨 掐絲琺瑯英雄雙聯瓶 Double vessel with mythical beasts (champion vase), 18th century. Qing dynasty (1644–1911). Cloisonné enamel. On view in Gallery 222. #MetChineseMasters #MetIrvingCollection

node.accessibility_caption: A blue cloisonné double vase with red, orange, blue, white, and gold  details. Between the two cases is a large gold phoenix standing on top of a bird and bear.
The reverse of the vase, with a dragon in the same place as the phoenix on the front. The backside of the creatures on the base on the front appear on this side.
Photo shared by The Metropolitan Museum of Art on August 08, 2021 tagging @metdrawingsandprints. May be art of cat.

node.text:
Cat's out of the bag and in the galleries this #InternationalCatDay. 🐈 ⁣
⁣
Cats have captured our collective imagination for centuries—just take a look across our collection! ⁣
⁣
Tap the link in bio to purr-use thousands (thousands!) of cats in the #MetCollection and discover humans' feline fascination. 🐾⁣
⁣
🐱 Nathaniel Currier (American, 1813–1888). The Favorite Cat, 1838–48. @metdrawingsandprints⁣
⁣
🐱 Unidentified ancient Egyptian artist. Cat, 664–30 B.C. @metancient⁣
⁣
🐱 Unidentified Chinese artist. Spring Play in a Tang Garden (detail), 18th century.⁣
⁣
🐱 Walker Evans (American, 1903–1975). [12 Portraits of a Cat] (detail), 1940s–50s. © Walker Evans Archive. @metphotographs⁣
⁣
🐱 Unidentified Moche artist (present-day Peru). Stirrup Spout Bottle with Cat, 4th–7th century.⁣
⁣
🐱 Hans Süss von Kulmbach (German, ca. 1480–1522). Portrait of a Young Man; (reverse) Girl Making a Garland, ca. 1508. On view in Gallery 626. @meteuropeanpaintings⁣
⁣
🐱  Unidentified Japanese artist. Sword Guard (Tsuba), 18th century. @metarmsandarmor⁣
⁣
[Image descriptions: A lithograph of a grey spotted cat.⁣
⁣
A blue faience statuette of a cat sitting upright.⁣
⁣
An ink scroll featuring a fluffy white and black cat prancing around in a lush garden. The cat crouches and looks upward from behind a stem of blooming red flowers.⁣
⁣
A black and white photograph of a striped cat standing on a kitchen stool.⁣
⁣
A grey ceramic stirrup bottle whose two spouts merge into the body of a cat at rest. ⁣
⁣
An oil painting of a young fair-skinned woman seated at a windowsill. She wears a yellow dress and works on a garland of forget-me-nots, one of which lies on the windowsill. Above her, a decoratively trailing banderole above reads, in translation, "I bind with forget-me-nots." To her right sits a large white cat.⁣
⁣
A metal sword guard featuring a raised depiction of a playful black cat and an elderly man in profile.]

node.text:
Your favorite #TeensTakeTheMet activity is back—@metteens is coming in hot with Teens Meme The Met! 😂⁣
⁣
Want to join the fun? Head over to @metteens and try your hand at creating clever captions for works in the #MetCollection. ⁣
⁣
📲 Screenshot blank templates, meme-ify them, and tag @metteens—they might just repost a few of their favorites. 👀⁣
⁣
Keep following @metteens for more fun all day as part of our first-ever, two-day global, virtual Teens Take The Met! Check out art-making activities, music, games, and more created in collaboration with more than 30 global partners.⁣

node.accessibility_caption:
A photograph of a ceramic seated figure who holds its hand up to its face. A superimposed caption reads "Me trying to remember why I walked into the room, forgetting what I came to grab."⁣
⁣

A painting of an older fair-skinned man standing within a green interior holding up a paper. His expression appears all-knowing. A superimposed caption reads "My face seeing the grade I got on my English paper knowing I didn't read the book and barely skimmed the SparkNotes.⁣
⁣

An ink painting of a bearded man depicted in profile seated at a cauldron. He is nestled between two lush trees. The composition is framed by Persian script. A superimposed caption reads: "Me obsessively waiting for the water for my boxed mac and cheese to boil.⁣
⁣

An oil painting of a fair-skinned woman in a white, long-sleeved dress and maroon floral hat. She leans against a striped couch and looks distracted. A superimposed caption reads "My face listening to my friend's new favorite song trying to understand why they like it."⁣
⁣
A weathered limestone sculpture of a virgin who clutches the shawl at her chest. A superimposed caption reads "Me pretending to be surprised when the person handing out baked goods offers me one."

node.text:
Photography meets DIY 📸

Hey @metteens! Today is #TeensTakeTheMet, so we've got a fun project to inspire you—create your own pinhole camera.

Before you begin, you'll need:

✔️ Cardboard Box with a Lid
✔️ Black Paint
✔️ Paint Brush
✔️ Aluminum Foil
✔️ Wax Paper
✔️ Black Electrical Tape
✔️ Pin or Toothpick
✔️ Scissors

Steps:
1️⃣ Paint your cardboard box black, inside and out. Pro tip: Give it a second coat of paint for extra coverage.

2️⃣ Using the outline of a cup, cut a circle into one side of the box. On the opposite side of the box, cut a 12 cm x 8 cm rectangle.

3️⃣ Cut a square of aluminum foil big enough to cover your circular hole, and tape it on the inside of the box. Using your pin (or toothpick), make a small hole in the center of the aluminum. This is your lens!

4️⃣ Cut a sheet of wax paper big enough to fit the rectangle hole and, tape it on the inside of the box. This will be the screen where you will see your image.

5️⃣ Tape the lid to the top of the box using your electrical tape.

6️⃣ Put a dark cloth over your head and point your camera towards a brightly lit area. You should be able to see an upside-down image in your box.

Bonus: Cut a small piece of cardboard to place over the lens. This will act as a lens cover!

Your pinhole camera is now ready for use! If you try this out, don't forget to share your creations with #TeensTakeTheMet. We can’t wait to see what you make!

P.S. Looking for more creative prompts? Head over to @metteens for more!
